Virginia.political_structure: House of Burgesses (1619), first elected assembly

events.title: Founding of Jamestown
events.description: First permanent English colony in North America, established by the Virginia Company.

events.title: House of Burgesses & Arrival of Africans
events.description: First legislative assembly and The first documented arrival of enslaved Africans in the English colonies that would become the United States was in late August 1619. Around 20-30 Africans, initially taken from a Portuguese slave ship by English privateers, were traded for supplies in the colony of Virginia at Point Comfort (present-day Fort Monroe). These individuals were then dispersed throughout the colony, marking the beginning of a system of slavery that would last for over two centuries.

events.title: Bacon's Rebellion
events.description: Colonial uprising against Governor Berkeley and Native policies.

events.title: Creation of Kentucky County, Virginia
events.description: Virginia organized its western lands into Kentucky County to manage frontier settlement during the Revolutionary War.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: Virginia becomes the 10th official state.

Massachusetts.reason_for_founding: Religious freedom for Pilgrims and Puritans

events.title: Mayflower Compact Signed
events.description: Pilgrims establish Plymouth Colony (Present Day Massachusetts) and sign a self-governing agreement.

events.title: Massachusetts Bay Founded
events.description: Puritans establish a major colony under John Winthrop.

events.title: Salem Witch Trials
events.description: Series of hearings and executions for alleged witchcraft.

events.title: Boston Massacre
events.description: British soldiers kill five colonists, inflaming tensions.

events.title: Boston Tea Party
events.description: Colonists protest British taxes by dumping tea into harbor.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: Massachusetts becomes the 6th official state.

New Hampshire.political_structure: Initially controlled by Massachusetts; royal colony in 1679

events.title: First Settlement at Odiorne's Point
events.description: Fishing village marks the beginning of New Hampshire.

events.title: Independent Constitution Adopted
events.description: First colony to draft a constitution after separating from Britain.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: New Hampshire becomes the 9th official state.

events.title: Maryland Founded 1634
events.description: Catholic haven established by Lord Baltimore.

events.title: Maryland Toleration Act 1649
events.description: Grants religious freedom to all Christians.

events.title: Statehood 1788
events.description: Maryland becomes the 7th official state.

Connecticut.reason_for_founding: Expansion and religious freedom for Puritans
Connecticut.cultural_religious_makeup: Puritan, but more liberal than Mass. Bay

events.title: Hartford Founded
events.description: Thomas Hooker, also for religious and political reasons, leads settlers and founds the town of Hartford.

events.title: Fundamental Orders Adopted
events.description: Considered the first written constitution in America.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: Connecticut joins statehood as the 5th state

Rhode Island.political_structure: Self-governing; separation of church and state

events.title: Roger Williams Founds Providence
events.description: Colony based on separation of church and state. Roger Williams seeks religious freedom after being banished from Massachusetts Bay Colony. It was one of several settlements that would later unite to form Rhode Island.

events.title: The colony of Rhode Island and the Providence Plantation
events.description: Colony comprising of Providence, Portsmouth, Newport and Warwick.

events.title: Declaration of Independence
events.description: Rhode Island was the first of the thirteen British colonies to declare independence from Great Britain. On May 4, 1776, the Rhode Island General Assembly passed an act renouncing allegiance to King George III, effectively declaring independence. This was two months before the other colonies declared independence with the signing of the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: Rhode Island becomes the 7th official state.

Delaware.political_structure: Shared governor with Pennsylvania, own assembly

events.title: Swedish Settlement at Fort Christina
events.description: Founded as New Sweden, becoming Delaware.

events.title: First to Ratify Constitution 1787
events.description: Becomes the first state of the United States.

New York.reason_for_founding: Trade and control of Hudson River

events.title: New Amsterdam
events.description: Founded by the Dutch as a trading post.

events.title: New Amsterdam Becomes New York
events.description: English seized control from the Dutch and renamed the colony to New York.

events.title: Zenger Trial
events.description: Landmark case for freedom of the press.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: New York becomes the 11th official state.

New Jersey.political_structure: Initially divided into East/West; later royal colony

events.title: Founded New Jersey
events.description: New Jersey was initially part of the larger New Netherland colony claimed by the Dutch, but it became an English colony in 1664 after the English took control. King Charles II granted the land between the Hudson and Delaware Rivers to two friends, Lord John Berkeley and Sir George Carteret, who named it New Jersey after the Isle of Jersey.

events.title: Battle of Trenton
events.description: Surprise Continental Army victory after crossing the Delaware.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: New Jersey becomes the offical 3rd state.

events.title: South Carolina Colony Founded
events.description: With North Carolina as one colony

events.title: Charleston Founded
events.description: Established as a key southern colonial port.

events.title: Carolina splits
events.description: By 1710, the Lords Proprietors recognized that the northern and southern sections of the Carolina colony were operating separately and successfully petitioned the crown to divide the colony by 1712

events.title: Stono Rebellion
events.description: Largest slave uprising in colonial British America.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: South Carolina becomes the 8th official state.

events.title: Charter to William Penn
events.description: Quaker colony founded promoting religious tolerance.

events.title: Charter of Privileges
events.description: Early document granting religious liberty and democratic rule.

events.title: Constitutional Convention and statehood
events.description: U.S. Constitution drafted in Philadelphia and Pennsylvania becomes the 2nd official state.

North Carolina.political_structure: Weak gov't; many settlers from Virginia

events.title: Carolina
events.description: Settled by Virginians and then part of Carolina; officially chartered as a colony in 1663.

events.title: North Carolina
events.description: Around 1663, North Carolina became a colony: Carolina, settled by the English and chartered by King Charles II.

events.title: Halifax Resolves
events.description: First formal call for independence by a colony.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: North Carolina becomes the 12th official state.

Georgia.reason_for_founding: Debtor haven & buffer from Spanish Florida
Georgia.political_structure: Initially ruled by trustees, then royal colony

events.title: Founding of Georgia
events.description: Last of the 13 colonies; founded by James Oglethorpe as a debtor's colony and buffer against Spanish Florida.

events.title: Joins the Revolution
events.description: Last of the 13 colonies to join the fight for independence.

events.title: Statehood
events.description: Georgia joins statehood as the 4th state

Vermont.reason_for_founding: Independence from New York and New Hampshire claims

events.title: Vermont Republic Declared
events.description: Vermont declares independence as an independent republic.

events.title: Vermont Becomes 14th State in 1791
events.description: Vermont joins the Union as the first state after the original 13 colonies.

Kentucky.reason_for_founding: Originally part of Virginia, Kentucky became the first U.S. state west of the Appalachian Mountains, formed to represent the interests of frontier settlers seeking more localized governance.
Kentucky.economic_focus: Tobacco, hemp, horse breeding, and frontier agriculture
Kentucky.cultural_religious_makeup: Predominantly Protestant settlers of Scots-Irish, English, and German descent; frontier culture with ties to Virginia
Kentucky.political_structure: Part of Virginia until 1792; then an independent U.S. state with its own constitution and legislature

events.title: Prior Statehood
events.description: Kentucky separated from Virginia and was admitted to the Union as the 15th state, becoming the first state west of the Appalachians.

Tennessee.reason_for_founding: Formed from North Carolina's western lands, Tennessee became the Southwest Territory in 1790 to organize frontier settlement and governance before achieving statehood in 1796.
Tennessee.political_structure: Originally part of North Carolina, then a U.S. federal territory, then statehood in 1796

events.title: Tennessee Becomes 16th State
events.description: The Southwest Territory is admitted to the Union as the state of Tennessee, the first U.S. territory to become a state.

events.title: Ohio Becomes 17th State in 1803
events.description: Ohio becomes the first state created from the Northwest Territory.

Louisiana.political_structure: French colony, Spanish colony, then U.S. territory

events.title: Louisiana Purchase
events.description: United States purchases Louisiana Territory from France.

events.title: Louisiana Becomes 18th State in 1812
events.description: Louisiana becomes the first state created from the Louisiana Purchase.

events.title: Indiana Territory Created
events.description: Indiana Territory separated from Northwest Territory.

events.title: Battle of Tippecanoe
events.description: A major conflict between U.S. forces under William Henry Harrison and a Native American confederacy led by Tecumseh, helping define territorial boundaries before statehood.

Indiana.reason_for_founding: Created from the eastern portion of the Indiana Territory as settlers pushed westward; Indiana became the 19th state admitted to the Union.
Indiana.economic_focus: Agriculture, land development, fur trade, transportation (canals and roads)
Indiana.cultural_religious_makeup: Primarily Protestant Anglo-American settlers, with remnants of French Catholic influence and diverse Native American populations
Indiana.political_structure: Became a U.S. state with its own constitution and elected government, transitioning from federally governed territory

events.title: Indiana Becomes a State in 1816
events.description: Indiana was admitted to the Union as the 19th state following the drafting of its state constitution in Corydon.

events.title: Indianapolis Becomes Capital
events.description: The state capital moved from Corydon to Indianapolis to accommodate central growth and settlement.

events.title: Illinois Territory Created 1809
events.description: Illinois Territory separated from Indiana Territory.

Illinois.political_structure: Part of Indiana Territory, then Illinois Territory

events.title: Illinois Becomes 21st State 1818
events.description: Illinois becomes a state.

events.title: Mississippi Territory Created
events.description: Mississippi Territory organized from lands ceded by Georgia.

Michigan Territory.reason_for_founding: Created to organize the northwestern lands of the United States after Ohio became a state and to manage increasing settler populations around Detroit and the Great Lakes.
Michigan Territory.economic_focus: Fur trade, lumber, Great Lakes shipping, agriculture
Michigan Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: French Catholic settlers, Native American tribes (e.g., Ojibwe, Potawatomi), and Protestant Anglo-American settlers
Michigan Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and judges

events.title: Territory Established 1805
events.description: Congress created the Michigan Territory from the northern portion of the Indiana Territory, with Detroit as its capital.

events.title: British Capture of Detroit
events.description: During the War of 1812, British forces captured Detroit, a major setback for the territory.

Northwest Territory.reason_for_founding: The Northwest Territory was founded primarily to organize and govern the vast lands ceded to the United States by Great Britain after the Revolutionary War

events.title: Northwest Ordiance
events.description: Established in 1787 by the Congress of the Confederation through the Northwest Ordinance, it was the nation's first post-colonial organized incorporated territory.The territory included land that would eventually become the states of Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin, and a portion of Minnesota.

Southwest Territory.reason_for_founding: The Southwest Territory was created to organize the land ceded by North Carolina to the federal government and to provide governance for settlers in the western frontier.
Southwest Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Predominantly Protestant settlers of Scots-Irish and English descent
Southwest Territory.political_structure: Federal territory with a governor appointed by the President of the United States

events.title: Formation of the Southwest Territory
events.description: The territory was officially created after North Carolina ceded its western lands to the federal government. Congress organized it as the Territory South of the River Ohio, commonly called the Southwest Territory.

events.title: Tennessee Statehood
events.description: The Southwest Territory was admitted to the Union as the state of Tennessee, becoming the 16th state.

events.title: Mississippi Becomes 20th State in 1817
events.description: Mississippi Territory becomes a state.

Maine.reason_for_founding: Fishing, lumber, and separation from Massachusetts
Maine.political_structure: Part of Massachusetts, then separate state

events.title: Maine Becomes 23rd State
events.description: Maine separates from Massachusetts as part of the Missouri Compromise.

Alabama.political_structure: Part of Mississippi Territory, then Alabama Territory

events.title: Alabama Becomes 22nd State
events.description: After Alabama Territory separated from Mississippi Territory in 1817, Alabama Territory become a state.

events.title: Missouri Territory Created 1812
events.description: Missouri Territory created from Louisiana Territory.

Arkansas Territory.reason_for_founding: Formed to organize the southwestern portion of the Missouri Territory as population increased and settlers expanded into the Mississippi River Valley.
Arkansas Territory.economic_focus: Cotton agriculture, land speculation, small-scale farming, fur trade
Arkansas Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Predominantly Protestant settlers of Scots-Irish and Anglo-American descent, enslaved African Americans, and Native American tribes (e.g., Quapaw, Cherokee, Choctaw)
Arkansas Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory governed by federally appointed officials, with a territorial legislature

events.title: Establishment of Arkansas Territory 1819
events.description: The Arkansas Territory was carved out of the southern portion of the Missouri Territory to manage increasing settlement in the region.

events.title: Little Rock Becomes Capital
events.description: Little Rock was chosen as the territorial capital due to its central location and river access.

Louisiana Territory.reason_for_founding: Established to organize the northern portion of the Louisiana Purchase after the United States acquired the land from France in 1803.
Louisiana Territory.economic_focus: Fur trade, agriculture, river commerce, land speculation
Louisiana Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: French and Spanish Creoles, Native American tribes, American settlers, Roman Catholic and Protestant communities
Louisiana Territory.political_structure: U.S. organized incorporated territory governed by federally appointed officials

events.title: Louisiana Territory Established 1805
events.description: The northern portion of the Louisiana Purchase was officially designated the Louisiana Territory, with St. Louis as its capital.

Orleans Territory.reason_for_founding: Created to govern the southern portion of the Louisiana Purchase, particularly the settled areas around New Orleans, following the U.S. acquisition from France.
Orleans Territory.economic_focus: Plantation agriculture (sugar, cotton), port trade, slavery-based economy
Orleans Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: French and Spanish Creoles, free and enslaved Africans, Native Americans, Roman Catholic majority
Orleans Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a governor appointed by the president; legal system blended civil (Napoleonic) and U.S. common law

events.title: Creation of Orleans Territory 1804
events.description: The U.S. divided the Louisiana Purchase, forming the Orleans Territory to govern the more developed southern portion around New Orleans.

events.title: German Coast Uprising
events.description: One of the largest slave revolts in U.S. history took place near New Orleans, highlighting tensions in the plantation economy.

Missouri.reason_for_founding: Louisiana Purchase expansion and fur trade
Missouri.political_structure: Part of Louisiana Territory, then Missouri Territory

events.title: Missouri Becomes 24th State in 1821
events.description: Missouri becomes a state as part of the Missouri Compromise.

Arkansas.political_structure: Part of Louisiana Territory, then Arkansas Territory

events.title: Arkansas Becomes 25th State 1836
events.description: Arkansas Territory becomes a state.

Michigan.reason_for_founding: Fur trade and Great Lakes expansion
Michigan.political_structure: Part of Northwest Territory, then Michigan Territory

events.title: Michigan Becomes 26th State
events.description: Michigan Territory becomes a state after the Toledo War.

events.title: Florida Becomes 27th State
events.description: Florida Territory becomes a state.

Florida Territory.reason_for_founding: Established to govern the lands ceded by Spain to the United States in 1819 under the Adams-Onís Treaty, and to formalize U.S. control over East and West Florida.
Florida Territory.economic_focus: Plantation agriculture (cotton, sugar), cattle ranching, timber, slave labor economy
Florida Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Spanish and French Creole influence, Protestant settlers from the American South, Native American tribes (e.g., Seminole), and enslaved Africans
Florida Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with federally appointed governor and legislature

events.title: Florida Territory Established 1822
events.description: After possession of East and West Florida, Congress formally organized Florida as a U.S. territory to manage settlement and administration.

events.title: Second Seminole War Begins
events.description: A long and costly conflict between U.S. forces and the Seminole Nation resisting removal from Florida.

events.title: Florida Becomes a State
events.description: Florida was admitted to the Union in 1845 as the 27th state following decades of territorial governance and conflict.

Unorganized Territory.reason_for_founding: Not formally organized by the U.S. government; referred to areas west of the Mississippi River, especially in the Louisiana Purchase, that were not part of any official state or territory. Designated for Native American resettlement under the Indian Removal Act of 1830.
Unorganized Territory.economic_focus: Limited Euro-American settlement; primarily used for fur trade and designated as Indian Territory for Native relocation
Unorganized Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Home to numerous Native American tribes (e.g., Osage, Sioux, Cheyenne, Comanche); some U.S. military and fur trade outposts; few American settlers
Unorganized Territory.political_structure: No formal territorial government; administered loosely by federal policies, military forts, and Indian agents

events.title: Indian Removal Act
events.description: Authorized the relocation of Native American tribes to lands in the unorganized western territories beyond the Mississippi River.

events.title: Indian Intercourse Act
events.description: Formally designated lands west of the Mississippi not in states or organized territories as Indian Territory. The Indian Intercourse Act refers to a series of six laws passed by the U.S. Congress between 1790 and 1834. These acts, also known as the Nonintercourse Acts, primarily regulated trade and interactions between European Americans and Native American tribes. A key aspect of these acts was establishing boundaries for Indian reservations and regulating the sale of tribal lands.

events.title: Texas Becomes 28th State in 1845
events.description: Republic of Texas annexed by the United States.

Iowa Territory.reason_for_founding: Formed from the western portion of the Wisconsin Territory to manage increasing settlement in the region and to prepare for eventual statehood.
Iowa Territory.economic_focus: Frontier agriculture, lead mining, land speculation, river trade
Iowa Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Primarily Protestant settlers from the Upper South and Midwest; displaced Native American tribes including the Sauk and Meskwaki
Iowa Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature

events.title: Creation of Iowa Territory 1838
events.description: Congress separated Iowa from the Wisconsin Territory due to population growth and the need for more localized governance.

events.title: First Constitutional Convention
events.description: Delegates met to draft a constitution in anticipation of statehood, but the proposed boundaries were rejected by Congress.

Iowa.political_structure: Part of Wisconsin Territory, then Iowa Territory

events.title: Iowa Becomes 29th State 1846
events.description: Iowa becomes a state.

Wisconsin.reason_for_founding: Fur trade and Great Lakes expansion
Wisconsin.political_structure: Part of Northwest Territory, then Wisconsin Territory

events.title: Wisconsin Becomes 30th State 1848
events.description: Wisconsin Territory becomes a state.

Wisconsin Territory.reason_for_founding: Created from the western portion of the Michigan Territory to govern the expanding population in the upper Midwest after Michigan pursued statehood.
Wisconsin Territory.economic_focus: Lead mining, lumber, agriculture, fur trade, frontier commerce
Wisconsin Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Primarily Protestant Anglo-American settlers, French-Canadian Catholics, Native American tribes (e.g., Ho-Chunk, Ojibwe, Menominee)
Wisconsin Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature

events.title: Wisconsin Territory Established 1836
events.description: Congress formed Wisconsin Territory from the remaining land of Michigan Territory not included in the new state of Michigan.

events.title: Iowa Territory Split Off 1838
events.description: The Iowa Territory was separated from Wisconsin Territory to accommodate growing settlement west of the Mississippi River.

California.political_structure: Spanish colony, Mexican territory, then U.S. territory

events.title: California Becomes 31st State
events.description: California becomes a state as part of the Compromise of 1850.

events.title: Minnesota Territory Created 1849
events.description: Minnesota Territory organized from Iowa and Wisconsin territorial lands.

events.title: Minnesota Becomes 32nd State
events.description: Minnesota Territory becomes a state.

Oregon Territory.reason_for_founding: Established to govern the jointly occupied lands of the Pacific Northwest after the Oregon Treaty with Britain, and to organize increasing American settlement along the Oregon Trail.
Oregon Territory.economic_focus: Fur trade, agriculture, logging, land claims through homesteading
Oregon Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Anglo-American Protestant settlers, French-Canadian trappers, Native American tribes (e.g., Chinook, Nez Perce, Cayuse), some Catholic missionaries
Oregon Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature

events.title: Territory Established 1848
events.description: The U.S. Congress formally created the Oregon Territory, which originally included present-day Oregon, Washington, Idaho, and parts of Montana and Wyoming.

Idaho Territory.reason_for_founding: Carved out of parts of Washington and Dakota Territories to manage the influx of settlers and miners after gold was discovered in the region during westward expansion.
Idaho Territory.economic_focus: Gold and silver mining, logging, agriculture, and later rail transport
Idaho Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Anglo-American settlers, Native American tribes (e.g., Nez Perce, Shoshone, Bannock), Chinese miners, and Mormon communities
Idaho Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature; subject to federal military oversight due to conflicts with Native tribes

events.title: Idaho Territory Created 1863
events.description: Congress created the Idaho Territory from parts of Washington, Dakota, and Nebraska Territories to govern the growing mining population.

events.title: Nez Perce War
events.description: A major conflict between the U.S. Army and the Nez Perce tribe, led by Chief Joseph, over forced removal from ancestral lands in Idaho.

Idaho.reason_for_founding: Carved out of parts of Washington and Dakota Territories to manage the influx of settlers and miners after gold was discovered in the region during westward expansion.
Idaho.economic_focus: Gold and silver mining, logging, agriculture, and later rail transport
Idaho.cultural_religious_makeup: Anglo-American settlers, Native American tribes (e.g., Nez Perce, Shoshone, Bannock), Chinese miners, and Mormon communities
Idaho.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature; subject to federal military oversight due to conflicts with Native tribes

events.title: Idaho Achieves Statehood
events.description: Idaho was admitted to the Union as the 43rd state following population growth and political organization.

Washington Territory.reason_for_founding: Created from the northern portion of the Oregon Territory to provide more localized governance for settlers north of the Columbia River as the region's population increased.
Washington Territory.economic_focus: Logging, fishing, agriculture, fur trade, maritime commerce
Washington Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Anglo-American Protestant settlers, Native American tribes (e.g., Duwamish, Yakama, Nez Perce), Chinese laborers, and remaining French-Canadian trappers
Washington Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with federally appointed governors and a territorial legislature

events.title: Washington Territory Established 1853
events.description: Formed from the northern part of the Oregon Territory, it included present-day Washington and parts of Idaho and Montana.

events.title: Treaties and Conflicts 1855
events.description: Several treaties with Native tribes were signed, leading to land cessions but also violent conflicts such as the Yakama War.

events.title: Washington Statehood
events.description: Washington was admitted to the Union as the 42nd state following rapid population growth and settlement.

Montana Territory.reason_for_founding: Created from the eastern portion of Idaho Territory to better manage the gold rush population and expand U.S. governance across the northern Rocky Mountains.
Montana Territory.economic_focus: Gold and silver mining, ranching, logging, railroads
Montana Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Anglo-American miners and settlers, Native American tribes (e.g., Crow, Blackfeet, Assiniboine), Chinese laborers, Catholic missionaries
Montana Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature

events.title: Montana Territory Created 1864
events.description: Congress carved Montana Territory out of Idaho Territory in response to rapid population growth and the need for localized governance.

events.title: Battle of the Little Bighorn
events.description: One of the most famous conflicts in U.S. history occurred in eastern Montana between the U.S. Army and a coalition of Lakota, Northern Cheyenne, and Arapaho warriors.

events.title: Montana Achieves Statehood
events.description: Montana was admitted to the Union as the 41st state, following population growth and political organization.

Montana.reason_for_founding: Created from the eastern portion of Idaho Territory to better manage the gold rush population and expand U.S. governance across the northern Rocky Mountains.
Montana.economic_focus: Gold and silver mining, ranching, logging, railroads
Montana.cultural_religious_makeup: Anglo-American miners and settlers, Native American tribes (e.g., Crow, Blackfeet, Assiniboine), Chinese laborers, Catholic missionaries
Montana.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature

events.title: Montana Achieves Statehood 1889
events.description: Montana was admitted to the Union as the 41st state, following population growth and political organization.

Washington.reason_for_founding: Created from the northern portion of the Oregon Territory to provide more localized governance for settlers north of the Columbia River as the region's population increased.
Washington.economic_focus: Logging, fishing, agriculture, fur trade, maritime commerce
Washington.cultural_religious_makeup: Anglo-American Protestant settlers, Native American tribes (e.g., Duwamish, Yakama, Nez Perce), Chinese laborers, and remaining French-Canadian trappers
Washington.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with federally appointed governors and a territorial legislature

events.title: Washington Statehood 1889
events.description: Washington was admitted to the Union as the 42nd state following rapid population growth and settlement.

Indian Territory.reason_for_founding: Designated by the Indian Intercourse Act as land west of the Mississippi River set aside for the forced relocation of Native American tribes under policies such as the Indian Removal Act of 1830.
Indian Territory.economic_focus: Subsistence farming, intertribal trade, some formal agricultural development among relocated tribes (e.g., Cherokee, Choctaw), limited commercial activity
Indian Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Diverse Native American nations including the Five Civilized Tribes (Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Seminole), Plains tribes (e.g., Kiowa, Comanche), with religious diversity including traditional Indigenous beliefs and Christianity
Indian Territory.political_structure: Not an organized U.S. territory; tribes governed themselves under treaties with the U.S. government; U.S. Indian agents and military forts enforced federal oversight

events.title: Post–Civil War Treaties
events.description: New treaties required tribes to cede parts of their land and accept formerly enslaved people as tribal citizens.

events.title: Dawes Act
events.description: Broke up tribal lands into individual allotments, undermining tribal governance and opening 'surplus' lands to settlers.

Oklahoma Territory.reason_for_founding: Formed from the western part of Indian Territory and the newly opened Unassigned Lands to provide formal governance for non-Native settlers following the Land Run of 1889.
Oklahoma Territory.economic_focus: Agriculture (wheat, cotton), cattle ranching, land speculation, railroads, and early oil exploration
Oklahoma Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Primarily Protestant Anglo-American settlers (many from the South and Midwest), Native American tribes in neighboring Indian Territory, Black freedmen, and European immigrants
Oklahoma Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and a territorial legislature; coexisted alongside Indian Territory until statehood

events.title: Oklahoma Land Run 1889
events.description: The first major land run opened the Unassigned Lands to white settlers, leading to rapid population growth and calls for territorial status.

events.title: Oklahoma Territory Established
events.description: Congress formally created the Oklahoma Territory from the western portion of Indian Territory, setting up a territorial government.

events.title: Sequoyah Statehood Proposal Rejected
events.description: Tribal leaders in Indian Territory proposed a separate Native American state, but Congress declined, paving the way for unified statehood with Oklahoma Territory.

Oklahoma.reason_for_founding: Designated by the Indian Intercourse Act as land west of the Mississippi River set aside for the forced relocation of Native American tribes under policies such as the Indian Removal Act of 1830.
Oklahoma.economic_focus: Subsistence farming, intertribal trade, some formal agricultural development among relocated tribes (e.g., Cherokee, Choctaw), limited commercial activity
Oklahoma.cultural_religious_makeup: Diverse Native American nations including the Five Civilized Tribes (Cherokee, Chickasaw, Choctaw, Creek, and Seminole), Plains tribes (e.g., Kiowa, Comanche), with religious diversity including traditional Indigenous beliefs and Christianity
Oklahoma.political_structure: Not an organized U.S. territory; tribes governed themselves under treaties with the U.S. government; U.S. Indian agents and military forts enforced federal oversight

events.title: Oklahoma achieves Statehood of 1907
events.description: Indian Territory was dissolved and combined with Oklahoma Territory to form the state of Oklahoma, ending formal tribal land sovereignty in the region.

events.title: Oregon Becomes 33rd State 1859
events.description: Oregon Territory becomes a state.

Kansas Territory.reason_for_founding: Organization of central plains under Kansas-Nebraska Act

events.title: Kansas Territory Created 1854
events.description: Kansas Territory organized under Kansas-Nebraska Act.

events.title: Bleeding Kansas
events.description: Bleeding Kansas refers to a violent period of conflict in the Kansas Territory from 1854 to 1861, stemming from the Kansas-Nebraska Act's controversial popular sovereignty provision regarding slavery. This act allowed residents of Kansas to decide for themselves whether to permit slavery, leading to fierce clashes between pro-slavery and anti-slavery settlers. The intense violence and political tensions during this era foreshadowed the larger conflict of the Civil War.

Kansas.reason_for_founding: Central plains settlement and slavery debate

events.title: Kansas Becomes 34th State in 1861
events.description: Kansas Territory becomes a free state.

Nebraska Territory.reason_for_founding: Organization of central plains under Kansas-Nebraska Act

events.title: Nebraska Territory Created 1854
events.description: Nebraska Territory organized under Kansas-Nebraska Act.

events.title: Nebraska Becomes 37th State in 1867
events.description: Nebraska Territory becomes a state.

events.title: Nevada Becomes 36th State 1864
events.description: Nevada territory created in 1861 from Utah territory,was seperated to form the state of Nevada.

events.title: Colorado Territory Created 1861
events.description: Colorado Territory organized from parts of Kansas, Nebraska, Utah, and New Mexico territories.

Dakota Territory.reason_for_founding: Created to govern the northern portion of the former Nebraska Territory as settlement expanded into the northern Great Plains following westward migration, gold discoveries, and railroad development.
Dakota Territory.economic_focus: Fur trade, farming, ranching, mining, railroad expansion
Dakota Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Sioux and other Plains tribes, Protestant Anglo-American settlers, German and Scandinavian immigrants, Catholic missionaries
Dakota Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with federally appointed governors and a territorial legislature

events.title: Dakota Territory Created
events.description: Carved out of the northern part of the Nebraska Territory, Dakota Territory originally included present-day North Dakota, South Dakota, and parts of Montana and Wyoming.

events.title: Dakota War of 1862
events.description: Conflict between the Dakota (Sioux) and settlers in Minnesota and the Dakota Territory following broken treaties and food shortages.

events.title: Black Hills Gold Rush
events.description: Discovery of gold in the Black Hills led to a rush of settlers and conflict with the Lakota Sioux, violating the Treaty of Fort Laramie.

North Dakota.reason_for_founding: Admitted to the Union when Dakota Territory was divided into North and South Dakota to manage population growth and political balance in the Upper Plains.
North Dakota.economic_focus: Wheat farming, railroads, cattle ranching, and milling
North Dakota.cultural_religious_makeup: German and Scandinavian immigrants, Native American tribes (e.g., Lakota, Dakota, Mandan), Protestant and Catholic settlers
North Dakota.political_structure: Formed as a U.S. state from the northern portion of Dakota Territory with its own elected government and constitution

events.title: North Dakota Achieves Statehood 1889
events.description: North Dakota was admitted to the Union as the 39th state, along with South Dakota, from the division of Dakota Territory.

South Dakota.reason_for_founding: Formed from the southern half of Dakota Territory due to regional population growth, political pressure for statehood, and the desire for better governance and representation.
South Dakota.economic_focus: Wheat and corn farming, ranching, mining (especially in the Black Hills), railroads
South Dakota.cultural_religious_makeup: German, Irish, and Scandinavian immigrants, Native American tribes (e.g., Lakota, Yankton Sioux), Protestant and Catholic communities
South Dakota.political_structure: Formed as a U.S. state from the southern portion of Dakota Territory with a state constitution and elected leadership

events.title: South Dakota Achieves Statehood 1889
events.description: South Dakota was admitted to the Union as the 40th state, simultaneous with North Dakota, marking the end of Dakota Territory.

District of Columbia.reason_for_founding: Established as the permanent national capital of the United States, intended to be independent from any state to avoid political bias and ensure federal control over national governance.
District of Columbia.economic_focus: Federal government administration, public services, lobbying, tourism, and education
District of Columbia.cultural_religious_makeup: Diverse population including African Americans, European Americans, and immigrants; religiously pluralistic with Protestant, Catholic, and other faith traditions
District of Columbia.political_structure: Federal district governed by Congress under Article I, Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution; limited home rule with no voting representation in Congress

events.title: Residence Act Passed 1790
events.description: Congress passed the Residence Act, establishing a federal district along the Potomac River as the permanent capital of the United States.

events.title: Federal Government Moves to D.C.
events.description: The federal government officially relocated from Philadelphia to Washington, D.C., marking the beginning of D.C. as the functioning U.S. capital.

events.title: Consolidation of D.C. Government
events.description: Congress created a unified territorial government for the entire District, replacing separate local governments for Washington City, Georgetown, and Washington County.

events.title: 23rd Amendment Ratified
events.description: Granted D.C. residents the right to vote in presidential elections for the first time.

events.title: Home Rule Act Passed
events.description: Granted D.C. limited self-governance, including an elected mayor and council, though Congress retains oversight.

Wyoming Territory.reason_for_founding: Formed from portions of the Dakota, Utah, and Idaho Territories to provide local governance for growing frontier settlements, especially along the Union Pacific Railroad.
Wyoming Territory.economic_focus: Cattle ranching, railroads, coal mining, agriculture
Wyoming Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Anglo-American settlers, Native American tribes (e.g., Cheyenne, Arapaho, Shoshone), Chinese railroad workers, Mormon communities
Wyoming Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature

events.title: Wyoming Territory Established 1868
events.description: Congress created the Wyoming Territory from parts of Dakota, Utah, and Idaho Territories to organize the sparsely settled frontier area.

events.title: Women's Suffrage Enacted 1869
events.description: Wyoming became the first U.S. territory to grant women the right to vote, setting a national precedent for suffrage and equality.

Wyoming.reason_for_founding: Formed from portions of the Dakota, Utah, and Idaho Territories to provide local governance for growing frontier settlements, especially along the Union Pacific Railroad.
Wyoming.economic_focus: Cattle ranching, railroads, coal mining, agriculture
Wyoming.cultural_religious_makeup: Anglo-American settlers, Native American tribes (e.g., Cheyenne, Arapaho, Shoshone), Chinese railroad workers, Mormon communities
Wyoming.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature

events.title: Wyoming Achieves Statehood
events.description: Wyoming was admitted to the Union as the 44th state, known as the 'Equality State' for its early support of women's rights.

New Mexico Territory.reason_for_founding: Established as part of the Compromise of 1850 to organize land acquired in the Mexican Cession and provide a territorial government over the former Mexican provinces of New Mexico and parts of present-day Arizona, Colorado, and Nevada.
New Mexico Territory.economic_focus: Ranching, small-scale farming, trade, and military outposts
New Mexico Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Hispanic (Nuevo Mexicano) Catholics, Native American tribes (Navajo, Apache, Pueblo), Anglo-American settlers
New Mexico Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature

events.title: Territory Established
events.description: The U.S. Congress formally organized the New Mexico Territory as part of the Compromise of 1850.

New Mexico.reason_for_founding: Formed from the land acquired through the Mexican Cession following the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, New Mexico Territory was established to govern the diverse population and strategic southwestern region.
New Mexico.economic_focus: Ranching, sheep herding, agriculture, trade (especially along the Santa Fe Trail), mining
New Mexico.cultural_religious_makeup: Hispanic (Nuevo Mexicano) Catholics, Native American tribes (e.g., Navajo, Apache, Pueblo), Anglo-American settlers
New Mexico.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and legislature until statehood in 1912

events.title: New Mexico Achieves Statehood 1912
events.description: New Mexico was admitted to the Union as the 47th state after decades of territorial status and efforts to prove loyalty to the U.S.

Arizona Territory.reason_for_founding: Separated from the western half of the New Mexico Territory to improve governance and respond to growing settlement, military needs during the Civil War, and geographic challenges.
Arizona Territory.economic_focus: Mining (especially silver and copper), cattle ranching, farming (with irrigation), and military outposts
Arizona Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Native American tribes (e.g., Apache, Navajo, Yavapai), Mexican-American Catholics, Anglo-American settlers, and some African American and European migrants
Arizona Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature; strong military and federal presence due to conflicts with Native tribes and Civil War tensions

events.title: Arizona Territory Created 1863
events.description: Congress officially separated Arizona from New Mexico Territory during the Civil War to improve federal control and administration.

Arizona.reason_for_founding: Separated from the western half of the New Mexico Territory to improve governance and respond to growing settlement, military needs during the Civil War, and geographic challenges.
Arizona.economic_focus: Mining (especially silver and copper), cattle ranching, farming (with irrigation), and military outposts
Arizona.cultural_religious_makeup: Native American tribes (e.g., Apache, Navajo, Yavapai), Mexican-American Catholics, Anglo-American settlers, and some African American and European migrants
Arizona.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature; strong military and federal presence due to conflicts with Native tribes and Civil War tensions

events.title: Statehood 1912
events.description: Arizona was admitted to the Union as the 48th state, completing the contiguous U.S.

Alaska Territory.reason_for_founding: Formally organized as a U.S. territory decades after its purchase from Russia to provide civil governance, promote development, and manage natural resources more effectively.
Alaska Territory.economic_focus: Fur trade, fishing, gold and mineral mining, later oil exploration, and military installations
Alaska Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Indigenous Alaskan groups (e.g., Inupiat, Yupik, Aleut, Tlingit), Russian Orthodox legacy communities, Anglo-American settlers, military personnel
Alaska Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a governor appointed by the President and a territorial legislature; under limited self-rule until statehood

events.title: Alaska Purchase of 1867
events.description: The United States purchased Alaska from Russia for $7.2 million, a move later nicknamed 'Seward's Folly.'

events.title: Alaska Becomes an Organized Territory 1912
events.description: Congress granted Alaska territorial status, giving it limited self-government for the first time.

events.title: Alaska Achieves Statehood
events.description: Alaska was admitted to the Union as the 49th state, prompted by Cold War strategy, economic development, and long-standing demands for representation.

Hawaii Territory.reason_for_founding: Established following the annexation of the Republic of Hawaii to formalize U.S. governance in the islands after the overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom. The U.S. sought economic and strategic advantages in the Pacific.
Hawaii Territory.economic_focus: Sugar plantations, pineapple farming, tourism, and military installations (especially Pearl Harbor)
Hawaii Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Native Hawaiians, Asian immigrant laborers (Japanese, Chinese, Filipino, Korean), American and European settlers, Protestant missionaries, Catholic and Native Hawaiian spiritual traditions
Hawaii Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a governor appointed by the U.S. President and a territorial legislature; Native Hawaiians lost sovereignty, and political control shifted to settler elites and U.S. interests

events.title: Unification of the Hawaiian Islands 1795
events.description: King Kamehameha I unified the Hawaiian Islands into a single kingdom, establishing the Kingdom of Hawaii as a sovereign monarchy.

events.title: Bayonet Constitution 1887
events.description: Under pressure from American and European settlers, King Kalākaua was forced to sign a constitution that drastically reduced the power of the monarchy and disenfranchised many Native Hawaiians.

events.title: Overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom 1893
events.description: Queen Liliʻuokalani was overthrown by a group of American businessmen and sugar planters backed by U.S. Marines. This marked the end of Hawaii's monarchy and began the push for U.S. annexation.

events.title: Republic of Hawaii Declared 1894
events.description: Led by Sanford B. Dole, the Provisional Government declared the Republic of Hawaii, excluding Native Hawaiians from power and resisting restoration of the monarchy.

events.title: Annexation by the United States 1898
events.description: The United States annexed Hawaii through a joint resolution (Newlands Resolution), during the Spanish-American War, valuing its strategic location in the Pacific.

events.title: Hawaii Becomes a U.S. Territory
events.description: The Organic Act made Hawaii an official U.S. territory, replacing the republic with a territorial government under federal authority.

events.title: Hawaii Achieves Statehood
events.description: Hawaii was admitted to the Union as the 50th state after a popular vote, although Native Hawaiian sovereignty movements continue to seek recognition and justice.

Hawaii.reason_for_founding: Established following the annexation of the Republic of Hawaii to formalize U.S. governance in the islands after the overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom. The U.S. sought economic and strategic advantages in the Pacific.
Hawaii.economic_focus: Sugar plantations, pineapple farming, tourism, and military installations (especially Pearl Harbor)
Hawaii.cultural_religious_makeup: Native Hawaiians, Asian immigrant laborers (Japanese, Chinese, Filipino, Korean), American and European settlers, Protestant missionaries, Catholic and Native Hawaiian spiritual traditions
Hawaii.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a governor appointed by the U.S. President and a territorial legislature; Native Hawaiians lost sovereignty, and political control shifted to settler elites and U.S. interests

events.title: Hawaii Achieves Statehood 1959
events.description: Hawaii was admitted to the Union as the 50th state after a popular vote, although Native Hawaiian sovereignty movements continue to seek recognition and justice.

Utah Territory.reason_for_founding: Created as part of the Compromise of 1850 to organize the central portion of the land acquired from Mexico; also established to provide governance for the growing population of Mormon settlers seeking religious autonomy.
Utah Territory.economic_focus: Agriculture, irrigation development, self-sufficient Mormon settlements, trade along emigrant trails
Utah Territory.cultural_religious_makeup: Primarily members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons), along with smaller numbers of Native American tribes and non-Mormon settlers
Utah Territory.political_structure: Organized U.S. territory with a federally appointed governor and territorial legislature; significant autonomy claimed by Mormon settlers

events.title: Utah Territory Established
events.description: Congress created the Utah Territory as part of the Compromise of 1850, encompassing land from present-day Utah, Nevada, Colorado, and Wyoming.

events.title: Utah War
events.description: Conflict between Mormon settlers and the U.S. government, which sent troops to assert federal authority in the territory.

events.title: Colorado Becomes 38th State 1876
events.description: Colorado Territory becomes the 'Centennial State.'
